Subject: Sequels and Series in Genre Fiction
Description: We all love that feeling we get when we can fully immerse ourselves in a fictional world.  Conversely, the return to the real world can be quite shocking.  Is this part of the reason for the prevalence of series work in genre fiction?  Is it something from the publishing side?  Is there a place for the stand alone work in SFF?  Speakers include:Mary Lynne Gibbs, Michael Cieslak, Robert Kroese - Track: Lit  - Duration: 50 minutes - Audio/video needs: none

Subject: Plotters vs Pantsers – Finding the Storytelling That Works For You
Description: Some writers are plotters, and can’t proceed until they know how everything ends.  Some writers are pantsers, and they surprise themselves as they go.  How can you figure out which one you are, and how can you harness the strengths of each approach while avoiding the weaknesses?   Speakers include:Ferrett Steinmetz, Michael Cieslak, Jim Leach, Robert Kroese - Track: Lit  - Duration: 50 minutes - Audio/video needs: none

Subject: When Did We Get Cool? The SFF Explosion on Screen
Description: In a world where some of the most watched shows deal with SFF themes or have been adapted from SFF material (Game of Thrones, The Walking Dead, The Lord of the Rings/The Hobbit, The Avengers et. al.) where does the “mainstream” line get drawn?  Why is it suddenly acceptable for the SFF genre to be viewed?  Has this translated over to the written word?  Side question: why has mystery always been more or less accepted but SFF is a more recent explosion?  Speakers include:Ernie Cline, Sean M. Davis, Michael Cieslak, Nicole Castle, Jim Leach, John Scalzi - Track: Lit  - Duration: 50 minutes - Audio/video needs: none

Subject: Obligatory Undead Panel: Is Undead Dead
Description: Shoot ‘em in the head, stake ‘em through the heart, the good old silver bullet...it doesn’t matter, the undead keep coming back.  Have zombies, vampires, and werewolves finally run their course or do these creatures still have legs?  Is there a division between genre fans who have grown tired of these creatures just as they’re taking off in the general public?  Speakers include:Mary Lynne Gibbs, Michael Cieslak, Sean M. Davis, Ken MacGreggor - Track: Lit  - Duration: 50 minutes - Audio/video needs: none

Subject: The Importance of Editing and Non-Writing For Would-Be Writers
Description:
Editing is an important part of creating a book, even if it isn't as sexy as, you know, actually writing.  We'll be discussing editing, query letters, and all of the business crap that comes along with doing this for a living.  Speakers include:
Mary Lynne Gibbs, Michael Cieslak, Rosemary Van Deuren - Track: Lit  - Duration: 50 minutes - Audio/video needs: none
